full_text: We need coal to make steel. We import it from Russia. Mining our own is the obvious answer, so open the new mine. If we do not help our steel industry more we will end up importing the steel, not stopping the  CO2.
Electricity demand low this morning but wind only managing 3%. Thanks to gas again the power stays on.
Will the government now tackle the high price of imported food and the shortage of home grown? See https://t.co/dkh8g5C3W5 for a proposal for a home grown food policy.
The best way to move on from the tax stories would be a     Budget to tackle the cost of living crisis with tax cuts for the many.
I want the Chancellor to rebuild his popularity. He should start by cancelling the National Insurance rise and suspending VAT on fuel. Ease the squeeze.

The Opposition have got their scalp of the Chancellor's wife. This is nasty politics. They send a clear message of intolerance to the rich and successful of the world. Do not come to the UK legally to create jobs, spend money and pay UK taxes as foreign nationals.

I want the Chancellor to cut the taxes he imposes on UK taxpayers, not to put up the U.K. taxes paid by his wife. The opposition is wrong to attack the wife of a politician instead of concentrating on how to make things better for the many.

I support the government aim of self sufficiency in energy. They now need to press on rapidly with the permits and investments that needs. All the time most people have gas boilers and petrol or diesel cars we need to get more domestic supplies to meet the demand.
The Opposition should not attack anyone for coming here legally and paying all U.K. taxes on work, jobs and investment  here. The Non Dom scheme is a good one for the U.K.

A strange move by Lib Dems to campaign for a VAT cut in local elections. Councillors levy the Council tax and decide how much to spend. They do not set VAT. Easy to promise something you know you cannot deliver.

The reports of  electric cars taking more of the market have not pointed out the main reason is the 55% fall in diesel and 25% fall in petrol car sales this March compared to 2021. It is proving easier to put people off buying new cars at all than to sell enough  EVs.
Great news that the Culture Secretary wants to find new investment, new ideas and a new partner to grow Channel 4 in a very competitive modern media market.

The world can only get to net zero if all main countries take tough action. The big emitters of CO 2 are not doing so. We need to look after ourselves with our own energy, food, and industry that can compete with them.

The latest figures show record levels of CO2 produced worldwide despite the U.K. and a few others cutting back substantially. China, Russia, India, the USA and the other large emitters do not bother to cut back, whilst we import from them. Why?

Just get on with extracting more U.K. oil and gas. It means less CO2 as well as a more reliable and cheaper supply and much more domestic tax revenue. The Regulators need to help us ease the energy squeeze, not delay or block progress.
On the doorsteps this weekend all the talk was about too much building, congestion and the cost of living.

Wind and solar power provides just 5% of our energy needs. Most U.K. people and industry need gas for heating and oil for transport. The government needs  more  U.K. gas and oil whilst we wait for the new nuclear and renewables with energy storage that could take  over.

Glad the government is about to tackle the UK's lack of domestic energy. We have relied too much on imports this century, running down home production. Home produced electricity, oil and gas is greener and generates a lot more jobs and tax revenue than imports.

Let's hope talk of an emergency budget to tackle the cost of living crisis leads to action. I'm ready to go to Parliament next week to help get it done. We should not be in recess with this outstanding.

The big hike in energy bills from today shows us we are short of electricity and gas. The government needs to take more urgent action to increase domestic supply and end our dangerous and expensive reliance on imports.
Today the cost of living crisis hits. The Treasury needs to take urgent action to cut taxes to offset more of the squeeze.

The NHS still will not tell us how many extra  medical staff they will recruit to bring waiting lists down, or how they intend to spend the extra money they say they need. They have plenty of managers so why can't they tell us?

Yesterday I  was pleased the government accepted advice some of us have offered and legislated  to improve safety reporting in the NHS. The Telford hospital report was shocking. Medics like pilots need to report all mistakes and near misses to prevent future deaths.
The Bank of England warns us of coming hit to real incomes and possible economic slowdown. The Chancellor needs to do more to offset the inflation.

National Grid tells us system struggling to handle very variable wind power. Large payments to wind farms not to supply at windy times, and days like yesterday or today when there is practically no wind power.We need more grid capacity and more energy storage to make wind work.

Another day of little wind. Gas generating 63% of our electricity, wind 1%, coal 5%. Good job we still have fossil fuel back up to renewables. Time to find more ways of storing wind power for the days of little wind.
As peace talks resume the EU should clarify when and how it will respond to Ukraine's application to join. Russia's violent invasion is trying to undermine Ukraine as a country with its own choices.
So now we read the Treasury will do more to ease the cost of living crisis. They need to do it now as April will see a big hit from energy prices, ill judged tax rises and food prices.
Why doesn't the Northern Ireland Office stand up to the EU and defend NI's position in the U.K. internal market? They could start by insisting on VAT cuts for the whole U.K.

When the government abolishes VAT on green products it needs to so for Northern Ireland as well as for GB.Nothing in the Protocol says the EU sets NI taxes. Clause 38 of the Withdrawal Agreement anyway puts us in charge of these things if we wish.

Next week government needs to take urgent and strong action to produce more of our own oil and gas. We cannot rely on imports from an energy starved EU now struggling to replace all that Russian gas they are still buying.
Glad to hear the government might do more to ease the cost of living squeeze. The sooner the better. The more the better.

I am writing to leading supermarkets to remind them many customers want to buy more U.K. food. They need to offer realistic prices to U.K. farmers at a time of big cost rises otherwise we will be short of domestic supply.

Opposition policy of an extra tax on any company producing  U.K. oil and gas is not what we need. We need to increase the jobs, investment and output of our oil and gas sector and stop relying so much on dear imports. Home oil and gas companies already pay double corporation tax.
The official forecasts show too big a fall in living standards to come. They also show the government is getting much more tax revenue than they expected so it could afford to do more to help.

The Chancellor invites ideas on tax changes to speed growth and investment for the autumn budget. Setting corporation tax at the Irish level of 15% would  work well and would increase revenues. The investment would pour in as it did in Ireland.
The Treasury found £105bn it was not expecting over the course of the year. They should have given more of this back to taxpayers to tackle the cost of living crisis.

The Treasury adds the inflation indexing of bonds where there is no  cash payment before maturity  to actual cash interest payments made on debt to spread unjustified gloom. The chart showing it has  the wrong description on it at the side.

They cut their borrowing forecast for this year by £50bn at the half year stage. Now they've cut it by £55bn more. They were £105bn out. Growth brings borrowing down, so lets have policies for more growth.

The  OBR forecast a deficit at least £75 bn higher for this year than it is going to be! So how come the Treasury insists they need an extra £12 bn National Insurance to square the books? They underestimated how much tax we are already paying by a large amount.
Last push by many Conservatives to cancel the National Insurance rise, the hated tax on jobs. The Chancellor has found extra revenue this year, so axe the  tax.

More nonsense today that producing more oil and gas at home will do nothing to  ease the squeeze. It will produce more UK  tax revenue,bring more better paid jobs and deliver energy that does not come from Russia or Saudi. It even cuts CO2 produced. What's not to like?

Margaret Thatcher's early tax rises hit growth and made her very unpopular. They were traditional Treasury austerity which harms. The later tax cuts and wider ownership led to growth and prosperity which was popular. Pity current commentary is as bad at history as at economics.
The government opposes the cheap wages hire and fire policy of P and O and has not changed employment law to allow it. It needs to take swift action to improve things.

This week the Treasury needs to show a new energy and determination to tackle the cost of living crisis. Tax cuts need to be supplemented with measures to boost U.K. output of everything from gas and oil to food and industrial products.

Pleased to see we had a good day for wind and solar electricity. We still need huge amounts of gas to keep home heating and industrial processes going. Some other day we will need fossil fuel back up for electricity when the wind does not blow.
Why does the Treasury try to sand bag so many good ideas to make this country more prosperous and self reliant by hiking so many taxes?

March 23 needs to be a full budget to tackle the cost of living crisis. A few pence off petrol would not be enough. Tackle NI, VAT on energy saving products, VAT on fuel. Promote more U.K. self sufficiency in gas and food.

Growers are saying they cannot afford to plant in greenhouses given the sky high energy prices. If we plant less that's more food inflation coming. Supermarkets and government need to help the growers.

P and O have treated their workforce so badly and are now failing to run services we need for imports. The government needs to help the employees. Not a good time to hike employment costs with a tax rise either.
When I go shopping I do not try to increase how much I spend but concentrate on getting good value things I need. Government should try that approach.

The government should stop talking about how much it spends on public services where more is better and concentrate on telling us about what it buys with all that money. We want better quality and better value for money.
People want to buy more home produced food. The supermarkets need to be realistic about the prices they pay farmers, and clear and honest with their labels.

Those  in industry and agriculture that rely on gas to heat and transform are struggling with sky high prices and carbon taxes. The government needs to take action to avoid more losses of factories and to secure more greenhouse plantings.

The government needs to tell us how much money Councils will get to help with Ukrainian arrivals. What back up accommodation is there if a sponsor cancels after 6 months? What tenant rights if any does a refugee enjoy?
What other country would refuse to produce its own gas, insisting on importing instead? The government says new wind farms are better, but they stop when the wind drops or when it blows too hard.

There is a fortune under our feet where there is onshore gas. Offer Councils and  landowners a royalty  if they were willing to let business get it out in their area. Volunteers  only. We need the energy and the money it would bring.
More U.K. gas is a better idea than more Saudi oil.
The Treasury still will not offer people relief from their tax attack on the eve of the cost of living crisis hitting. Why do they want so many people to be worse off?

The Bank of England printed too much money to cause the inflation. Now they are likely to put mortgages up to correct their error, increasing inflation further. They will make the cost of living crisis worse.
Will there be a minimum standard of housing to qualify for £350 a month? Will refugees have tenant protections? What happens if the landlord wants the rooms back? Need to rethink all this.

The government needs to change its Ukraine scheme. Why offer 3 years yet only guarantee 6 months rent free housing with no back up home thereafter? That's more worry and uncertainty for the refugee. Why £350 a month with no regard for what is provided?

Starving ourselves of gas will not suddenly switch all homes and factories to electricity. It just means higher bills. Producing more of our own gas eases the shortage. It also would be a tax bonanza for government allowing them to cut taxes to ease the cost of living crisis.

This decade we need more gas to fuel industry and heat  homes. We need to help ourselves and Europe by using more of the gas under our feet. Onshore production should happen by offering landowners and Councils willing to do it a share of the revenues. It can be volunteers only.
I agree with the NFU about growing more food at home. The U.K. is an unusual  country that spends most of its farming subsidies on stopping people growing food or on helping them exit farming.
When will the new Yorkshire  potash mine be in production? With sky high fertiliser prices we need it to help ease the shortage.
As the Chancellor completes his work for his  March 23 economic update many MPs have urged him to cancel the tax rises planned. I hope he now sees the need to ease the squeeze on living standards.

Glad the government now wants more domestic supply to limit the damage from global disruptions. Help people plant more wheat and grains. Issue new licences for oil and gas production now. Government departments still not doing the obvious.
When will  the Business Secretary get on and implement the new energy strategy he hinted at today? This is urgent now, with Europe  screaming for more oil and gas.

The government statement today implied they will now allow the UK to extract more of our own oil and gas to replace Russian imports. That's progress. Why didn't they simply announce which new fields and field expansions will now go ahead?
Once again the government Environment department fails to boost home produced food and fish despite the  obvious difficulties in relying on imports with surging prices and shortages.

Why are English fishing boats in our waters singled out  to meet new regulatory requirements with a system does not work properly? Government should make life easier for home vessels and boost our home industry.
Why isn't the Agriculture  department doing more to help farmers grow more grains? They  sound very complacent saying there is no shortage and we can rely on imports.
How much more industry will we lose by failing to back cheaper energy for our factories?
With oil and gas prices surging dangerously again, will the U.K. government now ensure we produce more oil and gas at home to give us some hope? Why the delay?

Message to the Business a Secretary. If you produce more gas it does cut the price. The US produces all its own gas and has  much lower prices than the U.K. as a result. You need lower gas prices to keep industries like steel and ceramics.
The best thing the U.K. can do to help Europe struggling with Russia is to produce more gas. We need to help cut  Europe's dependence on Russian gas which is paying for  the invasion of Ukraine.

The Fed, ECB and Bank of England judge policy on estimates of capacity and current output. They don't think enough about money and credit.What is U.K. capacity in anything given flex, and given wide access to global capacity?

Why do so many push the myth that Central Banks are independent? Governments own them, appoint their top staff and direct them. Why do these Banks keep getting it wrong - Exchange Rate Mechanism crash, Euro crises, great banking crash and now the post covid inflation?

Central banks created too much   inflation. They printed   too much money with zero rates for too long. Now war is pushing up energy and food prices further  they should not make the worse mistake of punishing us with too much tightening. Do not increase the misery.
Glad to hear the government promoting more investment in fruit and vegetable growing at home. Please get on with it and make it happen.We need to cut the food miles and the imports.

The U.K. government should do whatever it takes to increase domestic output of oil, gas and electric to help get out Europe out of its dependence on Russian supplies. Russia is waging economic war against us as well as violent war against Ukraine.

Why not use all the extra revenue from soaring oil prices to remove the National Insurance increase? We are all having to pay much more tax on fuel as the prices rise, with the government pocketing more than half the pump price.

Some in government tell me if we produce more of our own gas it will still be dear at world prices. They should look to see how US gas is only one sixth of the price of gas in the EU thanks to their domestic production, pipes and contracts.
Yesterday the government stressed the need for Europe to cut its reliance on Russian gas. I asked them again to allow more U.K. production to provide some more alternative supply.
The economic dislocation from the Russian invasion  and sanctions is another reason why the U.K. government should drop its tax rises and offer more help with the cost of living crisis.

The U.K. government must not let its wish to help Ukraine prevent it tackling the cost of living crisis, the  domestic energy shortage and the EU undermining Northern Ireland. The clock is ticking on all these problems.

Great to see Russian plans to occupy Ukraine and commit war crimes are being knocked back by the bravery of so many in a country who want  to be free and independent.The West needs to do more to undermine the Russian tax revenues and exports of energy which pay for the violence.

The Business Secretary needs to have urgent talks with U.K. oil and gas producers to work with them to get more oil and gas produced at home to help cut Europe's reliance on Russian fuels. It is EU/Germany's energy  dependence  that is preventing tougher sanctions.

Protesters trying to stop production of more U.K. gas and oil are helping Russia and the Middle East who will supply it instead. Why do we want them to have the tax revenues and jobs and not us here at home? Such protests do not save the planet but they worsen the energy crisis.
The National Security Council should now review our energy policy to put home produced  security of supply top of the list.

The Treasury is wrong about taxes. Why do they ignore the huge surge in extra tax revenues this year compared with their forecast, which happened with no tax rate rises? Growth brings the deficit down, not tax rises.

The Treasury inflates the debt interest figures by adding  to the real cash cost of paying interest on loans the indexation of the repayment value of the inflation linked debt which does not require any cash payments. It should concentrate on the cash interest costs.

The new surge in oil and gas prices will add to the cost of living squeeze with higher petrol and heating bills. Even more reason to drop the tax rises in April. Growth will be slowed more than enough without them.

With Russia threatening price hikes for gas shouldn't the UK government accelerate plans to produce more of our own gas? Gas is the transition fuel. Its greener, cheaper and safer to produce more of our own.

Yesterday I asked the PM if he will now apply the focus and innovation shown over vaccines to the cost of living crisis. Today's figures show the Treasury has collected many billions more in extra tax this year than forecast so we can afford to cancel the NI tax rise.

Getting rid of the pandemic controls and loss of freedoms will help jobs and livelihoods. Now we need freedom from excessive taxes to ease the squeeze. April will be the cruellest month if the extra taxes go ahead.
Before holding a summit with Russia President Biden needs to agree with Ukraine and NATO any concessions he wants to offer. What did Mr Macron tell Mr Putin to get the talks?

President Biden needs to spell out the much tougher sanctions he has agreed with Germany and other NATO members to make sure Russia is in no doubt about them. Germany needs to be clearer about future gas trade and pipelines.

Canada's PM  is dividing his country by his strong arm tactics against freedom protesters. In a democracy leaders need to find a way to allow protests or listen to protesters whilst keeping roads open.

When the PM returns from Germany we want him to win the war against the cost of living crisis. Cancel  the tax rises and drive for self sufficiency in energy at a time of the EU's dangerous dependence on Russian gas.

Glad to see new Brexit wins Minister going to make our trade easier by streamlining old EU procedures at our ports. Now he should go on to remove VAT on green products and put a Freeport into Northern Ireland.

If the government will not even take VAT off energy saving products to help the energy bill crisis it implies we have not taken back control of our tax system. We want to see some Brexit wins with less VAT, Freeports with lower taxes and the end of the  National Insurance rise.

The National Security Council should review U.K. energy and industrial resilience. We need to promote  more domestic energy and more electricity capacity. We need to attract and retain more steel, aluminium and glass making, microprocessor fabrication 
and home grown food.

If the EU does not stop breaking the Northern Ireland Protocol by diverting trade and alienating the Unionist community the U.K. government should take control of GB/NI trade. We should enforce the provisions that make clear NI is part of the U.K. internal market.

The Bank of England created too much money to give us inflation. It should not now take it out on us by slowing the economy too much. It has stopped printing so  inflation should fall after a peak this spring. The big cuts in real income will slow the economy anyway.

Europe is dangerously short of energy, shutting down more of its nuclear power and its coal. So will the U.K. government get on with making us self sufficient instead of working to make us depend more and more on EU energy imports?

Why did the Post Office hound so many post managers on false charges? I and some other MPs told them it was ridiculous to think hundreds of good honest staff all decided to become fraudsters at the same time just as they introduced a new computer system.

I thought the Canadian PM  was elected as a Liberal. Now he is using emergency authoritarian powers to shut down protests about his anti covid policies. So he is using an  anti freedom policy to stop protest against freedom restricting policies.

A Russian invasion of Ukraine would be wrong. The West has told Russia how we would respond. If the West now wants to talk more what if any are the legitimate Russian demands and what compromises will Germany offer? They must not suggest war could ever be justified.
Where is the staffing plan for the NHS to get the waiting lists down? The U.K. needs to train more people for the specialities in short supply.

Why does the U.K. government support President Biden encouraging US investment in onshore gas to keep prices low there but bans it here at home? Why is it better for us to import dear gas but fine for the US to have cheap home production?
It's the economy stupid.The Treasury and Bank have shifted too far from fostering inflation to slamming on the brakes. They are knocking confidence and stopping growth.

The Conservative fall in the polls comes from the cost of living crisis. The PM must stop the tax attack in April which will make it worse. Every policy should be reviewed to promote prosperity for the many.

Why does no-one else talk about the way the Treasury slashed its borrowing forecast for this year from £233 bn to £183bn, or how they are now £12.9bn lower than the revised forecast? Maybe they don't want us to know strong growth lowers the deficit without tax rises.
Russia says it is not going to invade Ukraine. The West says it would impose very damaging sanctions if Russia did. No need to keep repeating those positions.

At a Conservative lunch  yesterday no questions about parties. Anger at re wilding as they want more home grown food. Unhappy about importing so much dear energy instead of getting more of our own gas out of the ground.

Good that we had the fastest growth of the G7 last year. Pity the Bank  of England overdid the inflation by printing too much money.  Looks as if it is now going to tighten too much to stifle the growth. It's important not to overcorrect a past error.

Half the country has not wanted the free smart meters on offer. Now we hear they do want to use them to charge us more for using power at normal times. Always best to tell the whole truth from the beginning.

Glad the government is shifting its stance on domestic gas. We need a lot more domestic supply to replace imports of energy and goods. That will save U.K. energy using industry, cut CO2 and generate more tax revenue.

How much longer is the government going to put up with EU preventing GB to Northern Ireland trade? Their illegal action  has now brought down the power sharing executive and damages the Good  Friday Agreement. The U.K. should ignore  the border the  EU wants down  the  Irish Sea.
Why do critics oppose new free trade agreements because they might make some imports easier from non EU countries yet want to keep the EU Agreement which boosts EU goods into the U.K.?
The NHS needs a plan to recruit the extra staff it needs to tackle waiting lists. The extra money offered needs to be tied to spending that does deliver less waiting for patients.
Will the new Downing Street team now get the NHS to agree a plan with the Treasury to spend all the extra money offered to get waiting lists down?

When is the government going to enforce the Northern Ireland Protocol which pledges to support the UK's internal market and to be against trade diversion? They need to get the Unionists back to power sharing by taking their concerns seriously.

When will the Business department announce permissions and support for new domestic gas production to  generate more tax revenue and less CO2? When will they reduce their penal carbon prices which are forcing U.K. industry out of business, leaving us more reliant on imports?

The Treasury needs to push for better value for money from the NHS, but it should not delay the much needed clear the waiting list work. We have been waiting for months for an agreed recovery plan. Why?

As the Bank of England has decided to make us worse off by hitting the economy hard to correct for its past errors, the Chancellor should ease the tax squeeze to avoid a double whammy on living standards. It would also make him more popular.

The new team in Downing Street urgently need new policies. They should start with a new economic policy statement cancelling the tax rises, easing the squeeze and encouraging more domestic energy production.
Why does the Treasury want to hit the economy so badly with tax rises? And why does the Business department hit industry with sky high imported energy prices and carbon levies?

The Bank of England forecasts falling real incomes for two years, a slump in growth to 1% in 2023 and 2024, falling investment and rising unemployment. The government tax rises will do too much damage. Time to stop them.
Glad the Chancellor backs sound money. So why did he approve continued money printing last year after recovery was well set?
Good to see big changes at Downing Street. The PM needs fewer people but ones who know how to translate his vision into action, and how to run an efficient and well behaved office.
Instead of criticising Northern Ireland's First Minister for resigning, the U.K. government should blame the EU for breaking the Protocol and disrupting GB to NI trade.

There has been a large surge in imports from the EU and elsewhere into Northern Ireland as the EU has diverted trade from GB by its over the top interpretation of the Protocol. When will the U.K. government call time on this EU conduct which breaks an international agreement?

Double inflation  blow today. Huge increase of energy prices and likely increase in mortgages from Bank of England. The Bank will be hitting an economy already being slowed by the hit to real incomes.

Taxing us more through National Insurance to lend more money to power companies is not the way to ease the cost of living squeeze. Tax cuts and lasting cuts to fuel costs by producing more is what we need.

Yesterday I put the case for more  U.K. gas production in Parliament. Replacing imported LNG means more tax revenue, jobs and incomes at home. It also means less carbon dioxide is generated and strengthens  national security.

BBC 3 wants more regional content. Is that another attempt to break up England? Yesterday  the BBC cancelled a long promised meeting with me to discuss the BBC representing England as it does Scotland.
The BBC say they are short of money. So why are they re opening BBC 3? What can that offer that they cannot offer on all the current services?

The government proposes an electric revolution with many more to rely on electricity for travel and heating. So why is it planning under 1% growth in electricity generation in the U.K. by 2025 and under 10% by 2030?  Does it want power  cuts or even more imports?

Good to hear the government is thinking about EU laws to repeal. It should start by abolishing VAT on all green products and on domestic fuel. It should abolish the Ports directive and introduce a freeport in Northern Ireland.
Drop the policy of compulsory vaccinations for NHS staff. No need to make it more difficult to retain employees.

The Treasury Red book said this year the public sector would spend £230bn on health and £40 bn on social care. An extra £12bn from the new tax is under 5% , so what increase from other taxes are they planning?
£12 bn is a small addition to the NHS and social care budgets. What is the government promising to spend in total?
The government promises to spend all the £12 bn from the planned National Insurance tax hike on the NHS. What are they spending the  £76 bn extra in taxes they have collected so far this year on?

The Treasury  are hiking taxes on jobs, investment and business. This will squeeze people's incomes and mean less tax revenue than going for growth. Time for the low tax Chancellor to stop them and do what he says he believes. Lower taxes bring more growth and more prosperity.
The Treasury are about the hit our good economic recovery with their high tax wrecking ball. Why do they so hate enterprise and hard work?

Why do the BBC insist on using wrong numbers on the deficit? Do they not know the Treasury had to revise their deficit figure down by £50 bn at the half year stage because so much more tax revenue was pouring in? Still their forecast was too gloomy.

The Treasury are deliberately spreading fear about debt interest. They own a lot of the debt through the state owned Bank of England. The cash costs of interest paid is much lower than the number they use.

Why is the Treasury insisting on the extra tax on jobs when they got their sums so wrong in the budget? They have raised far more extra revenue than the £12bn they say they need. Now they want to take away the work from home tax allowance. They should ease the squeeze.
The U.K.  government needs to wrap up the talks with the EU and sort out the damage the EU has done to the U.K. internal market there. They have diverted trade, breaking the Agreement.
Plenty of momentum amongst MPs and the press to cancel the National Insurance rise. Come on government, do something popular for a change! I keep telling Ministers they are allowed to do good things.
The Treasury with their big April tax rises and the Bank with its suggested interest rate rises are clearly trying to prove the IMF wrong in their forecast of good growth for the U.K. this year.

The BBC wants to interview me about parties but has no wish to hear views on taxes, the energy shortage, the income squeeze, the wrong OBR forecasts of the debts and the policies to import more and  produce less. The public is less interested in past  parties  than  they  think.

The Treasury tells us they need an extra £12bn for  the NHS budget.They do not have a clue how much revenue comes in from all the taxes they  impose, underestimating it hugely. So come on PM, cancel the April tax rise.Tell the Treasury you  are  fed  up  with  false  pessimism.

Massive surge in tax revenues this year means government borrowing way below budget forecasts.Last month income and corporation tax take each  up more than 11%. They revised down the deficit by £50bn last autumn and still beat estimate. Why do they think they need  a  tax  rise?
Russia's control over the EU gas supply is a bad weakness for the West  in the current dispute. Why doesn't the U.K. government get on with getting more of our gas out of the U.K. North Sea?
Growing support for cancelling the National Insurance hike. Why doesn't the government just announce it? They seem to think they must not make any popular announcements.
Another government attempt to stop farmers growing our own food. Taxpayers money to switch to trees,to make us even more dependent on food imports. Why do they want to undermine our food supply?

Another cold day with little wind. Windpower is generating just 3% of our electricity, coal back on at  5% and plenty of imports. When will the government put in enough reliable capacity for our needs?

BBC Today programme unable to grasp in the first half of this year there has been a big rise in tax revenue thanks to growth. The Treasury didn't expect it so we can use that extra money and do not need the tax rises.
The Treasury overstated the deficit by more than £60 bn last year and by another £50 bn this year in their budget forecasts. So they do not need the big tax rises they threaten for April.
I read that the PM and the Cabinet want the National Insurance rise cancelled. When are they going to overrule the Treasury and cancel this wrong and hated policy?
Ministers say they want more domestic gas to cut our dependence on dear and unreliable imports. So when will they grant the permissions to drill and pump more from the North Sea?

Will Ministers launch policies to ease the squeeze and tackle the energy shortage? We hear too much infighting  about parties, who has the jobs and what whips said and not enough about the daily lives of people facing price rises and tight personal budgets.
The independent Bank of England has allowed inflation to soar when its main task is to keep it to 2%. The BBC never allows critics of these “experts” airtime to explain why they get it wrong.
The government should drop the compulsory vaccination policy for NHS staff. Not a good idea to make the staff shortage worse when  you are trying to recruit.

Glad the Business Secretary turned down another cable to import more energy from an energy short Europe. Now he should licence more domestic energy production which would help alleviate the shortage and high prices.
Cancel the National Insurance rise. Paying some people on very low incomes a one off payment is not the answer. NI penalises work, acting as a disincentive to work more hours or get promoted.

I have not discussed public money for my constituency with the whips. MPs put their  cases to the Ministers who make the decisions. The Ministers have to decide on their merits under the rules of the budget they control. Officials ensure due process.

The Bank of England printed too much money for too long as some of us warned. Now it threatens to punish us for its mistake by thinking of doing too much too late to correct a past mistake. They should let the economy weather the hit to real incomes without making it worse.

Inflation is too much money chasing too few goods. UK real incomes falling badly. Time for government to promote more domestic supply of energy, food, industrial products to stop the price rises. The imports best policy is disastrous.
Today the government should lift the covid restrictions. Case numbers are tumbling and the expert forecasts on hospital numbers were far too high.
Why is there no BBC England to match BBC Scotland? The BBC always wants to split England up into unloved  regions and deny its history and culture. Shades of the EU approach.

Laughable idea that the BBC represents all viewpoints as a truly national institution. It comes across as a net zero campaign organisation, wanting government to interfere in every aspect of our lives. It wants people on who fit its script of what we think to confirm its view.

I read we will be offered Operation Red Meat. So begin with U.K. energy self sufficiency, control of borders, no National Insurance rise and policies to grow and make more of what we need Here at home.

When I was a civil servant in Downing Street everything officials did in No 10 was designed to help and protect the PM and government strategy. There needs to be radical reform of the current set up with trust and the public interest at its heart.

Electricity demand low yet we still need to run the remaining coal power stations as there is little wind. Will the government at least now keep those coal stations until they have put in some more reliable power for when the wind does not blow?

As it appears Downing Street always did what it wanted the least it should now do is liberate the rest of us. Cancelling the tax rises they want to impose on people to pay for lockdown would also be a good idea as they just rub salt in the wound.

Wind is only managing 1% of our electricity demand today. Once again we are burning  all the gas we can and relying on more imports. Government must put more reliable power capacity in place as we cannot rely on imports from energy short Europe.

A half hearted relaxation from France for UK visits. Plenty of places to go on holiday that are friendlier, starting with the UK. If Mr Macron wants more visitors back he should  be friendlier himself instead of constantly seeking to undermine and criticise the UK.

I cannot understand why the very government officials who were imposing rules on the rest of us and telling us to obey them thought they did not apply to themselves. Clearly they did not think the rules were crucial to safety after all.

The officials who organised the event in Downing Street stopped the rest of us going to our places of work and told us it was too dangerous to do so. We had to work alone at home.  It appears they did not believe that by their personal organisation of their own work lives.

In the talks with the EU the U.K. must set out how we can allow free flow of trade between GB and NI without damaging their single market. The U.K. must say we will implement our proposals anyway,  which will conform with the Protocol and will restore our  internal  market.

Yesterday I asked the government why the new economic policy rules look just like the EU rules we used to obey. Looks like a Maastricht tribute act. We need to make controlling inflation and speeding growth the  central aims.

BBC R4 this morning tried very hard to get Virgin Media to change its mind about not imposing roaming charges to customers travelling in EU.  Sounded really angry they   will not impose them! Same old EU agenda when they could have asked more interesting things.
Those who brief that Mr Sunak should be the next PM should tell him imposing an avalanche of unpopular  and unwise tax rises will undermine  that ambition.

Mr Sunak is right to support cutting the isolation period for people who do not feel unwell. He is wrong to press on with damaging and unpopular tax rises which will cut living standards and slow the economy.
We are short of gas and it is too dear. We need to produce more of it. Extra taxes on our producers would make the problem worse, cutting investment and future output.

Glad Liz Truss is trying to force a sensible agreement on GB trade with Northern Ireland. The best answer is simply for the U.K. to take control of all internal U.K. trade and let it flow, as the  original Agreement implied. The EU constantly breaks and distorts the Protocol.
Time to rein in tests and isolation of people who do not feel unwell and let more back to work. Let vaccines, treatments and better air flow in buildings do their jobs.

More gas is the answer to a gas crisis. We need it to heat our homes and fuel our factories. We also need it as back up for electricity  generation when the wind does not blow or blows too much. Let’s have some more U.K. sourced gas as well as more windmills.
Sad to see the EU still leads the table for world deaths from covid, now over 900,000. The media often reports the lower USA number as the highest. Death rates very high in Hungary and Poland.

The Foreign Secretary needs to stand up to the EU over Northern Ireland and their diversion of trade. Restore the free flow of goods from GB that are staying within the U.K. There are ways of the U.K. doing this that are legal under any sensible reading of the Protocol.

If the government wants to level up it needs to encourage us to make and grow things people want to buy. It needs to cut tax rates, not increase them. It needs to allow more cheaper domestic energy supply.
If the government wants us to grow less food, produce less energy and stop making diesel and petrol cars how would it like us to earn a living?

The UK has just closed a nuclear power station and intends to close all but one of the remaining this decade. So what is the government plan to replace this? It looks as if the only plan is importing more, reducing national prosperity and security.
Taxpayers will have to pay to wild farmland, meaning we will grow less food at home. More food miles and CO 2 from all the extra transport for the food we need and fewer farming jobs. Why?
Why has Wales had more cases per million people and more lockdown than England?

Most countries with more restrictions still have plenty of virus cases. You cannot halt sufficient contacts to stop the disease as you need to keep much of the economy  working to supply food and keep the lights on.

In the third quarter of 2021 wind, solar and hydro produced just 24% of U.K. electricity thanks to the weather. We  need more reliable power to keep the lights on. Government should stop closing power stations that work and back more technologies not  weather  dependent.

More energy please 
https://t.co/AVhpeDS3z1
The EU now says gas is a green fuel. The U.K. should agree with them. The EU says it wants to import more gas from Russia. The U.K. should produce more of our own and not import from Russia.

The US President and the EU are rowing back on their COP 26 promises and are out to produce,buy and use more gas. The U.K. needs to produce more gas here to relieve the energy price squeeze. Affordability and reliability of power are crucial to jobs and living standards.
I set out in Mail on Sunday on line why we need to produce more UK gas https://t.co/HLeWnLTxme

The idea that we need a windfall tax on U.K. oil and gas is dangerous. We are short of energy so we need to allow and encourage the production of more UK  gas to increase supply. Taxing UK sources means more dependency on Mr Putin’s  gas and sky high european  prices.

We have an energy price crisis thanks to green subsidies, price controls, bans on new gas fields, and over reliance on wind. Doing more of the same will not solve it. We need a new energy policy that allows more home gas output and reliable electricity generation.
Let’s make 2022 the year to grow more of our own food and produce more of our goods. Government needs to use Brexit freedoms to make that easier and to buy British itself.
Happy new year. I want the government to implement key promises in the 2019 Manifesto to make it happier. They could start with promised new measures to reduce energy bills.
Why do so many CV 19 test kits come from China? As the NHS is buying so many can they speed up more domestic production so all that  cost provides more U.K. jobs and incomes?

The PM was right not to impose new restrictions on England for Christmas and new year. The  Health Secretary should do more work on air extraction and UV cleaning in public buildings and on infection control in hospitals.

The Conservative 2019 Manifesto promised no increase in the main taxes and control of energy bills. I look forward to helping the government deliver those promises. Stopping the tax rises and increasing domestic energy supply would help.

Why do the Welsh and Scottish devolved governments like bossing people around and telling them how to run  their lives? Why aren’t their CV 19 numbers better? Time to trust people more and for government to legislate less.

Poor retail sales after Christmas may not just be about covid but also about the coming squeeze on incomes. Government needs to cancel the tax rises and urgently increase the supply of energy. Its  tax and energy policies are doing damage.

BBC Today’s interview on the energy crisis was a proposal to put in more wind farms when one of the main reasons we were short of energy this year is the fact the wind did not blow much. No questions over what back up power is needed when the wind drops.

Lending more money to UK  energy companies will not solve the problems of dear energy.   Government price controls bankrupt too many businesses pointlessly, leading to big price rises anyway.  We need more gas supply not more taxpayer subsidies for wrecked  businesses.

The U.K. government blocks new oil and gas production at home. President Biden hands out 3091 drilling permits in his first year and auctions oil  leases  on  80 million acres of the Gulf. US gas prices as a result are affordable whilst UK wholesale gas is hugely expensive.
A BBC Today interview on U.K. high energy prices. No mention that more domestic supply is needed to reduce the shortages needing very dear imports!

Why did BBC Today say the problem of energy prices is international energy prices which we cannot do anything about? US gas prices are way cheaper than ours because they allow business to find and produce more gas. We in the U.K. should produce more of our own energy.

Price controls on energy do not work if the government will not allow companies to deliver enough energy. The subsidies and taxes imposed to affect which power is produced have to be paid by consumers and help leave us short of energy.

The Business Secretary  needs to understand shackling the U.K. to an EU energy system that is short of gas and reliable electricity will mean high prices and shortages. Time to expand the domestic supply of gas and put in more  generation that does not need  the wind to blow.

With better treatments, more vaccines, better infection control, better air circulation in public buildings we now need to live with CV19 like other infectious illnesses. Time to move on from legal controls on peoples lives.
Happy Christmas to you all. Have a great day with your nearest and dearest. Enjoy the spirit of giving and kindness.

It takes a lot of gas to make bricks, tiles and ceramics. Shortages and high gas prices are threatening our industry. BBC Today shut down talking about this. Why do so many want to stop us making things here? The U.K. needs to deliver more gas.
Glad the Foreign Secretary has stuck to the U.K. position about the Northern Ireland Protocol. Time to take control of NI to GB trade and stop the EU interfering in our internal market.

Energy is in short supply with very high market prices.Price controls bankrupt suppliers but do not deliver any more power. Later the prices go up anyway. Government needs to grant permissions and incentives to produce more.
Natural gas is a lot cheaper in the USA where they allow more investment in domestic supply.
How does the BBC do it? Their Today programme expert on energy did not think producing more of our own gas when there is a shortage would help!

We have just lived through more days of little wind power. The electricity industry had to burn a lot more gas helping drive gas prices even higher. We need to put in more generating capacity for when the wind does not blow which does not rely on gas or coal.
There’s one way to respond to the gas price crisis that will help sort it out. Allow more gas production from the big unused reserves we have at home. Turn on the gas taps and drill the extra wells.
I’ve been warning for a long time that stopping us producing energy and relying on imports would create shortages and sky high prices. Will the government now act given the gas price crisis?
Good news that a Scottish study finds Omicron a lot milder on average than delta, just as South African data showed. Time to re run the forecasts.

I am looking forward to both seeing the clock and hearing Big Ben for new year. It was cruel timing to cover the nation’s icon in scaffolding when voters wanted to restore their sovereignty through Parliament.

The science briefing yesterday confirmed it is too soon to know how mild or serious Omicron will be and when its growth rate will start falling. The official forecasts suggest a lower peak in intensive care than for previous wave.

There needs to be more informed sharing and discussion of the data on how many people have serious illness from Omicron requiring intensive care. Why no media interest in the government/NHS answer I got saying they cannot yet predict likely serious case load?

BBC Today kept interrupting Iain DS , then failed to ask key questions of NHS rep.  What is happening to intensive care numbers? How many got Omicron in hospital rather  than going in with it? How long do Omicron  patients  need  to  stay  in  hospital?

A Minister has replied to my question about hospitalisation rates. They say they are not using the scientific forecasts of a surge in Omicron to plan extra beds as there is no reliable data on severity or transmission yet to base such action on.
If the government wants advisers speaking in news conferences they should have advisers worried about jobs and non covid health as well as covid specialists.

Today I ask the Health Secretary to clear up the confusion in his Telegraph article yesterday between the fast growth in Omicron cases and total case numbers. What matters is the total, not just one mutant.

We need more accurate and extensive data and better forecasts from the government scientists. As they like communicating direct with the  media they should be asked tougher questions  about their forecasting records.

In this continuing period of little wind we are very dependent on imported electricity and have to use old coal stations when demand is high. The government needs to establish more reliable domestic generating capacity.
Parliament should meet next week. Need to cancel National Insurance rise and remove VAT from fuel. Need to examine any new evidence on how Omicron might affect NHS.
Sorry to see Lord Frost leave the government. The PM must not give in to the EU over Northern Ireland. The U.K. must take control of GB to Northern Ireland trade.

Ministers need to be given a range of scenarios for covid hospitalisations and deaths with probabilities to inform a debate about appropriate responses. Until the evidence is clearer we should not  rule out better outcomes with vaccines helping and an average milder illness.

As the people said to be breaking the lockdown rules in government were civil servants it was obviously crucial the senior civil servant investigating should be clearly innocent. How come the civil service could not get that right?
So the government advisers are cutting their forecasts of likely new covid infection rates. Why did they put out such pessimistic views in the first place?
Great response to my Brexit elf Christmas story on https://t.co/yndVB9jN9P
PS The BBC Today programme did do the pre record.
BBC up to usual tricks. Invited me on for a live on Today at 7.10. I agreed. After hearing what I might say they cancelled and are talking about a pre record later! No surprise there.
If the Chancellor wants to help the country he should cancel his increases in National Insurance . Take VAT off domestic heating fuel.
The way to cut the inflation is to produce more of our own energy, not to put  mortgage rates up.

Will the Chancellor now admit his high tax economic slowdown is wrong? Will the Environment Secretary back British farming instead of trying to stop us growing our own food? Time to listen to Conservatives.

I have had an answer to a Parliamentary Question confirming there are no official forecasts of possible hospitalisation rates for Omicron because they do not know how much of it is mild or without symptoms..
When will the government make more decisions to increase the U.K. supply of gas at a time of dear and scarce imports? Home produced gas would be greener and cheaper than some of those imports.

Ofgem wants to increase imports of electricity by installing more subsea cables to the continent. They should instead be promoting more UK jobs and domestic security of supply. Europe is short of energy and dependent on Mr Putin for gas.

Today I urged the Minister in the House to press the Post Office  to apologise and to settle promptly and generously with the Post Office mangers they wronged over the Horizon computer system. Good news the government now agrees this was a disgrace.

The BBC has been grilling Conservative MPs who voted against any part of the government proposals as if they were running the whips office. Apparently MPs should not ask difficult questions of government experts or query any official judgement.

Today Ministers will use their coalition with Labour and the SNP to push through laws many disagree with. Ministers should think again as the policy is not stopping the virus but does economic  damage.

Why are there official plans  for more cables to the EU to import yet more electricity?  We need to produce more of our own energy and electricity, not less. The EU is energy short and cannot be relied on. They rely on Mr Putin.
The latest Omicron measures will hit hospitality, travel and entertainment jobs and businesses again. More reason to cancel the coming National Insurance increase to limit the damage to incomes.

Great leader in Telegraph urging changes in the NHS similar to ones I have been proposing. Marvellous defence of freedom from Graham Brady, Chairman of Conservative backbench MPs. Please read these PM.
The Chancellor keeps putting taxes up whilst telling us he is a tax cutter. Time to do what he says he wants to do. What’s stopping him?
Treasury tax rises to come have slowed the economy to a halt. That will increase the deficit, not lower it, and increase the cost of living squeeze.  Why did they do it?
Michael Gove gave us no shred of evidence to support his gloomy outburst. The latest scientific statements tell us the vaccines work against the new version of the virus.

Today a leak of more curbs on our freedoms to come just before Christmas as Parliament closes for recess.  What is the evidence that we will need this? How do they know already? Where is the leaked economic advice about the damage this would do?

If Ministers must have officials by their side to present the anti virus policies can we have some balance? We need an economic adviser as well as a scientific adviser, and we need a non covid medical adviser as well as a covid specialist.

The PM must  speed the report into parties by officials at No 10. He must take action against any who broke the covid rules as  they were the rule makers telling the rest of us to obey.  Time to work closely with a slimmed down team he trusts.
Today I am asking the Health Secretary to put in some more hospital beds so we have more NHS capacity. That would be a good use of the extra money.

No need to replace Allegra Stratton. We will be better off without that role. Her view  that other people should buy electric cars but not her, and  advice on how to use a dishwasher did not provide value for taxpayers.
I expect a record number of Conservative MPs to vote against these latest restrictions. Many more this time round do not think a good case has been made.

Trying to impose new restrictions now in the run up to Christmas would be a bad misjudgement. If civil servants had a party against the rules last year they should tell us and apologise. No one is naming an Minister or MP as  present.

Yesterday I asked the Health Secretary why some of the extra cash for the NHS is not being spent on extra beds and medical staff in our hospitals. Also why didn’t the NHS use the Nightingales for CV 19 to keep more  of the other hospitals free for other work?
I read that the Chancellor and PM are going to seek better value for money in government. They should begin with the NHS reorganisation and management costs, and the Test and trace Budget.
Glad to read the Chancellor wants to be a tax cutter. He should start by reversing the planned National Insurance hike, and uphold all the Conservative Manifesto tax promises.

The Greens polled just 3.8% in the Bexley by election and the Lib Dems even less. 3 months of the BBC using COP 26 to push their net zero policies daily as essential to our future seems to have put most people off.

Yesterday the U.K. needed to burn coal again to keep the lights on. When is the government going  to have a reliable strategy to generate enough power when the wind does not blow or when it blows too much so wind turbines are shut down?
The government’s decarbonisation policies will just mean we import more things from countries that burn fossil fuels. How does that help us or save the planet?

Why does the Agriculture department want to stop us growing food and make us more import dependent? It’s not the policy we want to cut the food miles and rebuild our farms after the damage of the Common Agricultural Policy.

Why is the cost of hotels for people the smugglers brought here a secret? When will there be more progress in closing down the criminal businesses that set out to undermine our borders and risk lives in dangerous boats?
https://t.co/dkh8g5C3W5 up and running again
Points of Order  today in the Commons on how the extra money is being spent in the NHS, where is the manpower plan and how will they get the waiting lists down?
I have asked the web service provider  to get https://t.co/dkh8g5C3W5 running again as it is currently down.
It’s not a great human right to be able to undertake an illegal sea journey on a dangerous boat which might end in death for the passenger. We need a legal way of ending this dangerous trade.
The new rules on isolation if you have been in contact with a suspected carrier could mean too many people who are well and not infected have to isolate.
The Netherlands has cases of the new CV 19 variant so why is it not on the red list for travel when countries in Southern Africa are?
Where is the new EU plan to stop people smugglers and dangerous small boats in their waters?
Government seems to think vaccines work fine against new variant. Is there any evidence it leads to more serious illness for most people than other variants?
If President Macron wants to stop so many people dying in French waters from people smuggling boats he might need to adopt some of the U.K. suggestions in the PM letter.

High time the EU sorted out how so many illegal migrants end up at Calais from various safe countries. I wish their meeting success today. The EU needs to end so many camping in the cold in North France.
Good conversation with Iain Dale last night for an audience in Wokingham Town Hall. He backed Boris, and was critical of President Biden’s Afghanistan and economic policies.
Good that the experts think the vaccines will work against the new variant. No-one wants a lockdown for Christmas.
Why do the French police just watch people launching small boats crammed with too many people so they are unsafe?

France should enforce her own laws to stop the death boats. People running cross channel ferry services have to gain licences, use safe equipment and pay taxes. Why don’t they stop the ones who ignore these rules?
I am urging the governments to do more to find and arrest the people making big money out of people smuggling.

A tragedy that our constant urging people not to risk small death boats in the channel was ignored yesterday.Particularly upsetting that young children's lives are risked by adults who should protect them from such obvious dangers.
The Treasury needs to get better at directing  spending to the things  that matter so it can ease its tax squeeze on the economy.
I hear  the Treasury has time to brief about the state of No 10. Any chance of their doing some work on securing value for money from the NHS spend they authorise?
Peppa pig is  a colourful example of successful entrepreneurship and private sector investment. Cut taxes Prime Minister to have more such good stories to tell.
When will  the government set out benefits for industry investing in Freeports? There has been delay and dilution of the original idea.
The government needs to rethink its social care plan, starting with better funding for Councils facing a large bill. The tax they have planned will only pay a fraction of the total cost.

Ministers have long set a clear policy to end illegal asylum boats . They provided money, people  and other resources to stop the migrant trade. They now need to take control to get the policy followed.

In the October borrowing numbers the Treasury seems to have cut its forecast for borrowing this year by £50bn compared with March. That’s the result of good growth in the first half. Trouble is they are now slowing the economy with their tax policy.

The Treasury is keen to impose austerity. It now worries about the increase in inflation linked debt, which is not a cost we have to pay until maturity. The best way to get the debts under control is to go for growth, not tax rises.
The EU now says it wants to negotiate properly over Northern Ireland trade. They are the ones who have undermined GB/NI trade so they can solve it easily if they withdraw their blocks on it.
The U.K. government is going to help protect the Polish border. Can they also protect the U.K. one?
The government needs to get on with its new legislation to stop the dangerous boats across the Channel. We need an update from Border Force on catching the criminal gangs behind it.
The NHS reorganisation rolls on with little publicity. I am asking how much it costs and what advantages it will bring us.

There will be quite a squeeze on people's budgets in April next year with energy price rises, Council tax rises and the National Insurance hike. The government should cancel the tax rise now to ease the strains.

Why does the media ignore Germany's continuing dependence on lignite for electricity and the expansion of strip mining? Will a new German government close down more coal or stick with a 2038 timeline?
We need to worry more about non covid causes of death as the NHS adjusts its workload and spending priorities after the pandemic surge last year.
The extra money voted for the NHS needs to be spent on expanding capacity. That means more doctors, nurses and hospital beds. As we spend more so we need to be able to do more.
The government should stop threatening people with tax rises and bigger loan repayments. The squeeze on incomes is too big.

The best COP 26  can say is try again next year. China, Russia and  India, 3 of the biggest producers, have no intention of cutting their CO2 output. Germany and Poland intend to carry on with mining and burning coal.
What progress is there with identifying and prosecuting the people smugglers running dangerous small boats across the Channel? These are serious crimes putting people at risk of drowning.

Why has the media been highlighting the Belarus migration problem but not the migration by small boats from  France? Glad to see the U.K. government said current levels unacceptable. We need a solution.

COP 26 arithmetic says that adding up  all the current national plans shows carbon dioxide output will be higher in 2030. It seems the main producers of CO2 in the world do not want to try to come off fossil fuels, as China, India, Germany and others carry on burning coal.

Today's remembrance of the Great War of 1914-18 reminds us of the blessings of peace. We owe it to those who lost their lives in conflict to look after and value our freedoms and deter those who would threaten them.

The EU's so called compromise for GB to Northern Ireland trade requires the "construction of permanent border control posts" and every UK internal market item to have electronic EU paperwork. Not the offer if you want to help.

Glad to read the U.K. is getting ready to trigger Article 16 to start to sort out GB/NI trade. The government must show how the EU has trashed the Agreement by diverting trade and by its absurdly disproportionate action on the GB/ NI border against our internal trade.
When is COP 26  going to discuss how to offer more affordable and popular green products to the public? There has to be more buy in to changes to heating, eating and travel modes.

If the Bank of England wants to do more to curb inflation it should immediately stop creating more money and buying up bonds. Raising interest rates whilst buying bonds to keep them down would be contradictory.

The Prime Minister asks countries to do more to cut carbon dioxide. He needs to concentrate on those who refuse to in order to sell things to us that green rules stop us supplying ourselves. That does not save global CO2 but steals our jobs and incomes.

Many of us want the waste plastic out of the oceans. That requires many people around the world to stop throwing litter around. The U.K. government cannot solve the problem for all the countries that fail to dispose of rubbish safely.

U.K. government officials want to cut U.K. carbon dioxide output. They also need to keep the lights on, let us grow enough of our own food and allow more better paid industrial jobs. Importing everything that entails CO2 does not save the world but does undermine the U.K.

Watching the BBC’s relentless enthusiasm for net zero policies I wonder why they never ask why the Green Party only got 2.7% of the vote in the last election. They promised the quickest and toughest  way to net zero. Green policies need popular buy in to work.

France still wants to make the U.K. an EU colony after we have left by its wrong view of the Agreement. Lord Frost must tell them the U.K. is going to control our own fishing grounds and take control of GB to Northern Ireland trade.
As COP 26  tries to phase out coal China expands it use and pours out more carbon dioxide. The BBC fails to interview a rep of China and ignores Germany’s continuing reliance coal. Why?

Where is the NHS plan to get the waiting lists down? They tell me they have not worked out what extra staff they might need and have not costed how much of the National Insurance rise they will spend.

This should be the ideal  week for the railways to show us how good they can be for travel. Instead we have seen big delays to Glasgow and then a worrying derailment and crash. More work needed to provide a great and safe service.
Not a good look that a President arriving with a big motorcade gets in to COP 26 but a Minister in a wheel chair is held up.
The  EU Treaty requires them to have special relations with neighbouring states to promote peace and prosperity. Just another of their Treaty laws France breaks.
With several of the largest carbon producing countries intending to increase their emissions more this decade the world is not even starting a journey to net zero any time soon.

President Biden comes to Glasgow without an agreement within his own party of how much the world’s second largest CO 2 producer should spend on reducing emissions. President Xi, the biggest  CO 2 producer, announces China will go on increasing its output. Not a good start.
How many delegates and leaders are flying to Glasgow to tell others not to use jet travel? Why wasn’t COP 26 an on line event? It is easier lecturing others how to live if you follow your own advice.

China, Russia, Brazil, India - the big carbon dioxide producers - are lining up to avoid meaningful commitments to make changes. That means we should not close down things here in order to import from them.
So France and the EU want the U.K. back as a colony. They look mean and desperate trying to boss us about so they can take more of our fish and try to annex Northern Ireland.

As long as U.K. stays polite and resolute it is France not us that loses  credibility in the world. Glad to see the French Minister admits it would be damaging to stay in the EU when we are told it must be more damaging to leave.

The UK needs to get firmer over fishing rights. Lets ban supertrawlers of over 100 metres damaging our fishing grounds and taking too many of our fish. The French are risking their businesses by acting so irresponsibly.

Before releasing large new sums to spend the Treasury needs to agree how the money will be spent. People want to know there will be big improvements if they have to pay more tax. When I go to a shop I want to see the goods before passing over the payment.
The continuing collapse of new car output is not just a shortage of chips. High U.K. taxes on new cars and the coming ban on new diesel and petrol vehicles is also having an effect.
Glad the Chancellor  believes in lower taxes. No need to make them a reward for economic recovery. We need them now to speed that recovery.

Given the big surge in tax revenues so far this year compared to gloomy official forecasts, the budget should go for more growth. It’s the best way of bringing  the deficit down. Lower tax rates are what is needed.

When do we get the plans to run down the one off pandemic spending? Where is the plan to run railway services for the  new pattern of working, to drive down the huge losses? Government needs to spend wisely.
The government needs to worry about inflation. Higher public sector wages are a good idea as long as government works smarter, raising productivity. Where are the plans for that?
£6 bn more to get NHS waiting lists down on top of most of the £12bn new tax next year. By how much will the lists fall for this cash? Where is the agreed plan signed off by NHS top management?
The budget needs to show the Chancellor is indeed a lower tax Conservative.

The pre budget stories are all about more spending. What about the extra £46 bn tax the Treasury has taken year to date above the March forecast? Doesn’t this show we do not need new taxes and tax rises?
Scrap the NI surcharge.

The government is worried about the slow take up of booster vaccines. If they read their own website they will see you cannot book a booster on it until 6 months and one week has elapsed from second dose.

In 2005 the world burned 85 million barrels a day of oil. Industry forecasts expect the world to burn 100 million barrels a day from next year. What difference will COP 26 make to the wish of most countries to increase their use of fossil fuels?
China, Russia and India are three of the top five carbon producers in the world. If COP 26 is to succeed they have to start cutting their use of fossil fuels which they do not want to do.

The European Central Bank is teaching Germany to like more inflation as it carries on creating billions of Euros. The retirement of the Head of the German Central Bank, the ECB’s leading anti  inflation  hawk, will make their task easier.

Why is the Bank of England still creating more money and buying up more government debt when it is worrying about inflation? Instead of threatening borrowers with a rate rise it should stop its printing press. Interest rate rises will not train and recruit more lorry drivers.
Borrowing this year so far is running £43.4 bn below the official forecast. Why did we need the tax rise for next year? OBR needs to get more realistic with its estimates.

Yesterday I asked if the stronger protections for ancient woodlands in the Environment Bill would have saved the woods HS2 is cutting down. The government seemed to imply Yes. Pity they did not hold that view when deciding on a bad investment.

Yesterday I suggested a way for government to work with the Regulator and water industry to eliminate most sewage discharges to our rivers. The government seems to agree more needs to be done to clean up our rivers.
The Treasury keeps threatening more and new taxes. We need to promote a better recovery which means encouraging jobs, investment and business, not taxing them more.

When I asked the government today  what plans they have for increased generation of green electricity for when the wind does  not blow there was no clear answer. We need to get on with putting in more power generation to meet the needs of the electrical revolution.

For a heat pump to be green we need all our electricity to come from reliable renewable sources. The government needs to get on with requiring more green electricity capacity in the U.K. We currently depend on imports and gas .
Today Parliament remembers the work and life of  Sir David Amess. I urge the government to look at the causes he held dear and do more to help them as their tribute to a fine MP.

No media reports of plenty of diesel and petrol and filling stations with available pumps. The next scare stories to try to create a supply crisis should be treated more sceptically. Creating runs on goods that are available in normal quantities is unhelpful.

Today I will ask the government to put in more back up power generation for when there is no wind or sun. There are old stations that can be kept on stand by or converted to biomass. We need more electricity available.

We must ensure our representative traditions continue as David Amess would wish.  Violence must not stifle open debate nor the safe access  of MPs to constituents  views. Margaret Thatcher spoke the morning after the Brighton bomb to make  the  point  murderers  do  not  win.

David Amess was a friend and a dedicated constituency MP. I will miss him and mourn his passing. He cared so much about his area and the people he represented. My thoughts are with his family after this brutal murder.

The EU proposals for the NI Protocol do accept they have damaged the U.K. internal market on trade,breaking the Agreement. They still fail to fix the EU’s wish to control NI and to legislate for it against the wishes of the Unionists.

The latest Irish/ Northern Ireland trade figures show that there has been a big diversion of trade to the EU. This is a clear violation of the NI Protocol by the EU and shows they made GB/NI trade too difficult to bring this about.

Latest figures show economy is being  slowed by higher taxes and threats of interest rate rises. Government should cancel the National Insurance rise. More growth is needed to get the deficit down. We are still not back to pre COVID level.

Railfreight is part of the answer to the problems of traffic congestion and shortage of lorry drivers. Need to use it more . A pity electricity is now so dear it is switching to diesel locos, but it still is a good option.
Big global companies short of computer chips. Brazil short of coffee. China short of electricity. Shipping rates through the roof. World gas prices very high.  Doubtless some will blame Brexit!

So now the EU accepts it has been disrupting and diverting GB to NI trade and should relax a bit. Time for the U.K. to take control of all trade within our internal market. The Protocol is damaging and wrong.

The Treasury needs to control spending instead of wanting more tax rises. Controlling illegal migration would cut hotel bills. Reforming the nationalised railway could reduce the losses. Cutting the office space the civil service does not use could help.
The Business department may have won a battle with the Treasury but needs to tackle the underlying problem. It needs to help get more affordable UK gas to UK industry rather than financial support.

Why do the Treasury and some at the Bank of England want to slow the economy with  tax and interest rate rises when we have only just started our recovery from lockdowns? They will make the deficit worse, not better.

When is the Business Secretary going to set out an energy policy that allows us to keep industry here  whilst industry still relies on gas? We do need to take urgent action to avoid closures of energy intensive plants.
The Business department wants Treasury help with the sky high price of gas. They run energy policy, so why don’t they licence more UK production to cut expensive imports and increase supply?

Why does the government want to leave our steel, glass, paper, ceramics and other energy intensive industries facing big shortages of energy? Why does it propose to put up their tax rate on profits when they will not have profits to tax in these conditions?
Glad to read some Cabinet members want to try to stop the tax rises planned for next year. The last thing we need now is a further squeeze on living standards and business from the tax threats.

Why doesn’t the government take immediate action to increase reliable UK generating capacity and increase domestic gas output? Price controls cannot stop price rises coming unless we produce more energy .

UK energy is too dear. We import too much and are vulnerable to world price spikes. The government needs to back more UK electricity and gas output. You cannot sustain industry with such dear gas prices.

I am told the NHS bosses do not know how many Chief Execs the NHS has and does not know what it is spending this year on private sector  health care help. So how do they know they need £12 bn more next year? Why can’t they tell us how much that would reduce the waiting lists?

I asked how much the NHS is  spending on work by private hospitals and on  capacity availability. They said they were discussing this with the  private sector. Why can‘t they tell me the budget? Why don’t they know what they have spent  in  the  first  half  of 2021-2 ?
The Health Department tells me they do not know how many Chief Executives the NHS in England employs. Why not? They recruit them and pay them. Surely you need to know to manage the budgets.
I ran down the fuel in my tank all the time there were queues. Able to buy some  yesterday when there were no cars waiting on the road to reach the pumps.
China, India and Germany are increasing their use of coal and mining more. Can COP 26 persuade them to stop? Replacing coal power stations must be a key priority.
Ignore France’s threats of illegal action and get on with restoring our fishing grounds  and GB/Northern Ireland trade.
The UK has been made too dependent on imported gas and electricity. We are now subject to big world price rises and foreign threats. When is the Business  department going to promote more UK energy?

It is not green to close our energy intensive industries down, only to import fossil fuel based products from less green countries. The UK needs to produce more of our own gas to relieve shortages.That means licences and tax changes.
