It`s time to train more people for skilled work here in the UK instead of always looking abroad for new employees. Not enough people get the chance to move up in their job with training and investment to get them into a better paid job

UK state debt is not as high as the official figures pretend, because the Bank of England has bought in around one quarter of it and we own the Bank of England. Important  not to exaggerate. State  interest payments are low relative to spending thanks to low interest rates.

Let's hope someone can take on Flybe services after the complex financial problems. We need good transport links. Banks also  need to work on facilities for good businesses with turnover temporarily badly affected by the virus.

Levelling up is a great government agenda. We do want more better paid jobs and more private sector investment outside London. Government can help with better transport systems and roads and lower taxes on success and enterprise.
Hope the Bank of England joins in concerted world action to offset the virus driven downturn. Fed and Bank of Japan leading the way.
Time to cut taxes to offset World downturn. Cut IR35. Give all small business a 3 month business rates holiday. Remove VAT from green products and domestic fuel. Cut Income Tax rate.

Home Office should get on with recruiting the extra  police, cutting crime and putting in the new borders policy. The government has a clear agenda to implement and the Home Office has plenty of officials to do it.
We need to grow more of our own food. Bad idea to write off farming. Government agrees we need to cut the food miles and boost UK output.

The Fed is putting money into the banking system to help the economy. China is doing the same and making cheap loans available to businesses damaged by the virus impact. The ECB is doing QE. When is the Bank of England going to wake up to the need to respond to the virus shock?

Cut taxes now. The world economy is being badly hit by the virus. The government needs to boost the UK. Tell the Treasury to stop obsessing about  debt rules and put some consumer power into the global battle against recession and slowdown.
Glad the UK is refusing to make more concessions to the EU. It's time for the EU to wake up to the need for them to give ground if they want privileged access to the UK, their former Treasury Island.
World stock markets are signalling a bad slowdown, with several overseas economies likely to go into recession. It's time to boost the UK economy with tax cuts so people have more money to spend.
Time to fight world recession. The markets are giving a warning. Bring on the increased spending and the lower taxes we need.
Raised with government the need to stop building on floodplains to cut flood risk. Government Planning Inspectors do not always take the risks seriously.
The Home Secretary is right to ask her  department to implement government policy as promised to voters. Its a pity some  see fit to brief against her for expecting timely actions and good results.

Mr Macron doesn't think the EU can manage a Free Trade deal this year. In which case he had better prepare for not having one. Would he like EU style high  tariffs imposed by us on all that French wine and food they sell us?
We need a larger anti floods programme. No more building on floodplains. More river dredging and cleaning. More bunds and water barriers. More pumps and water channels in wetlands.
Glad government is pressing on with free ports. They should be Enterprise zones as well. Let's show the UK is truly open for new business.

The EU rows over the budget remind them they are losing a big net contributor this year. Most important we stop paying them  soon and spend the money on our priorities. Tax cuts for all and better budgets for  schools and hospitals

We need to boost the UK economy to offset the big slowdown in China. Their car sales collapsed this month owing to shutdowns. Japan was hit last quarter by tax rises and this quarter by trade and virus effects.

Owen Patterson is right that we need a new anti floods policy using our freedoms outside the EU. Pumping and dredging are important. Ending new development on floodplains is crucial. Wokingham should rule out all development on low lying land prone to flood.

The Home Secretary is right to want a new Immigration policy and right to repatriate foreign criminals. These policies have been awaiting implementation since 2016. I am sure senior officials can deliver this in good time,so thanks to all those who are helping do so.
The UK must stay firm with EU. Time for them to shift position and come to us.
The EU want access to the UK, their Treasure Island. We import so much more than we export to them. The question is what are they offering us to get better access for their goods than WTO terms?

There is no need for long and acrimonious talks with the EU. If the EU want a Free Trade Agreement we can have one. If they do not want to honour their promise of one we should just leave. We do not need to pay to trade.
The Fed are boosting the economy  by # 60BN a month. China has put in £200bn and the ECB is doing E20bn a month. Why is  the Bank of England not helping fight the global downturn?
The US Fed is boosting the economy by $60 billion a month. China has put in £200 billion and the ECB is doing E20 bn a month, all to fight the world downturn. Why is the Bank of England not helping?

The PM was right to want a new economic policy that promotes growth. His main adviser is right to challenge Treasury thinking which has been too pessimistic and has helped create the slowdown we experienced last year

Time to respond to the government consultation on First Homes, a discount scheme for some to buy new build properties. See my comments on https://t.co/XWUitdW203. We do need to help more people become owners.

Glad to read the new Treasury  team wants to speed growth and prosperity. Tax cuts for all are needed. Get VAT off things we don‘t want taxed. Cut Stamp duties on homes and VED on cars. Reduce  business rates. Add Enterprise zones to Freeports. We need a boost as the world slows.

You cannot tax people into prosperity. You do not make the less well off rich by taxing the rich out of the country or by taxing entrepreneurs to take fewer risks and run fewer businesses. I wish the new Chancellor every success in making  the case for enterprise and prosperity.

Glad to see the Treasury and No 10 want to  work in harmony to promote the growth agenda. We need change at the Treasury to implement the vision of prosperity for the many, not austerity, and for levelling up, not keeping down.
When we welcome people to come and live and work in the UK we want them to have good homes, school places and NHS care. This takes time and money to provide so we do need new migration controls.

A popular green policy is to protect more of our countryside from overdevelopment. The government's new control on migration should reduce the pressure for more homes which will help. I want lower housing targets in Wokingham in the next plan
Good to hear EU Commission saying they are fine with an Australia style deal or a bespoke Free Trade Agreement. So let's get on with it. No need to argue  over it all year.
The UK has cut its carbon dioxide output more than other countries. Time for Germany and China, two big sources of CO2, to get their CO2, output down to nearer UK per capita levels.

In Wokingham I’m asking the Council to ease congestion at  traffic light junctions by improving the phases and using traffic sensors. Winnersh crossroads, the lights at Wokingham Station level crossing and King Street Lane to the Winnersh by pass all need changes.
Let’s get the UK on the move by tackling congestion. 4 way traffic lights should be switched to two way with right filters to increase capacity substantially at busy junctions.
The Treasury should be talking tax cuts not tax rises. The world and the UK economies need a boost and some optimism as the UK Prime Minister offers
When is the Bank of England going to ease credit and liquidity as the Fed, Peoples Bank of China and ECB are doing? We need to help boost the global economy
There is more need than ever for a budget boost and a Bank of England stimulus as China is now in economic trouble and will slow the world economy more

How much are people prepared to pay for green energy and new heating systems? In Chile and France there were protests against green charges and taxes. We need to work with the grain on saving fuel use to lower bills, not to make travel and heating luxuries for  the rich.

The USA has much higher GDP per head than the EU. The UK is above the EU average but also considerably below the US. We need to follow a growth policy that gets us nearer US levels of income now we are free to choose the best policies that work.

The EU told the car industry to make and sell diesel cars to cut CO2, then changed to being anti diesel once big investments had been made. Now there is also doubt about whether hybrids are green enough. The car industry needs clear guidance about future policy.
No more concessions to the EU. Let's take back control. https://t.co/j1gaT4ezn5
No more concessions to the EU. They need to make us a good offer to secure privileged access to our lucrative market. We did not leave in order to stay under their rules and demands.

President Macron does not understand Brexit. He thinks more central control is what is needed, when people reacted against EU powers and the way they are used. He thinks the EU can force the UK to accept its laws,  when  we  clearly  voted  to  leave  the  single  market.

Now we are out we need to use our new freedoms. The government could start by announcing the end to VAT on the items we think should not be taxed. The country deserves a Brexit bonus as we throw off the Maastricht austerity rules.

Tonight's historic change needs to be followed by firm whilst friendly negotiations with the EU over our future trade arrangements. There must be no more UK concessions. We must take back full control of our laws, our money, our fish and our borders.

Tonight we at last leave the EU. I am proud of UK voters for wanting  to be independent and self governing . They  reaffirmed it  in the recent election. The voters have belief in our ability to do well by governing ourselves.  They removed MPs who did not share their optimism.
We need to speed up worthwhile infrastructure investment. One way to help is to offer compensation up front to people affected by a project.
Our fish should not be on the table in the free trade talks with the EU. We should be planning a much bigger UK fish catch whilst taking action to protect our fishery better.
HS2 means more large investment in the south and London. Let's have more rail investment in the North instead.
Cancel HS2 and spend more on early rail improvements for commuters into all main cities where we are short of capacity.
One piece of advice to the government in its EU negotiations - just say No to demands for more concessions.  No was the word Mrs May would never use which is why her negotiations failed.
There is a simple answer to the French demand to take our fish  - No. Or to avoid any misunderstanding -   Non.
The US and EU clashed at Davos over green growth. Why does Germany still produce and burn so much lignite given EU views on coal?

If a Council switches traffic lights from only allowing one way on a four way junction to proceed on green to allowing two ways  with right filters there will be less congestion and more use of the road capacity.
We need to tackle congestion and get the UK on the move. There are many traffic light sets with bad phasing. Tell your Council to reprogramme the lights to cut the delays.
President Trump called for a US/UK trade deal and said he wants fair and reciprocal free trade. Worth working to get a good agreement, remembering we do not have to sign up to things we don't like.
Set out today ways to get faster growth in jobs, wages and investment in the UK in a Westminster Hall debate I led. More details on https://t.co/XWUitdW203

Good news that the UK was  third in the world after US and China for attracting tec investment last year  with more than Germany and France combined. We need to make more cities magnets for new tec to match London.

London has twice as many businesses per 1000 people as much of the rest of the country. The budget needs to remove obstacles and offer help through lower taxes and easier set ups to encourage more businesses outside the capital.

Good to see Downing Street wanting a pro growth budget. We need tax cuts to stimulate more self employment, more new businesses and more activity alongside better transport and broadband and more spending on schools and NHS. We need to grow the tax base by backing enterprise.

The Chancellor is right that we need to make our own laws and rules so we can be better off. The EU  has damaged some of our industries where we want to do better. We will not lower employment standards or standards of protection for the natural world.

The EU is more the supplier and the UK is more the customer in our goods trade. Instead of threatening us the EU should want to secure free access to our lucrative market. Time for them to improve the tone and make concessions if they want a deal.

The EU should honour its agreement and negotiate in good faith otherwise we must just leave. They shouldn't scare monger about EU citizens who are welcome to stay in the UK but should set out their offer to UK citizens.

So the Bank of England now thinks maybe it should cut interest rates. Why did it slow the economy so much by monetary tightening in the  first place? Why did it squeeze banks and credit so much? Why did it ignore the global move to stop the slowdown?

More money for the NHS, schools and police is good. We also need tax cuts for growth. Good time to save some money by cancelling HS2 and replacing it with lower cost earlier improvements in the commuter railway into our cities and towns.
I welcome the extra money for Wokingham and West Berkshire schools where we now know the individual school amounts. I am querying one school which looks too low.

China’s Central Bank has been changing the banking rules to promote growth. The Fed has  been putting cash  into the markets and cutting rates to promote growth. China and the USA are growing faster than the UK. Where is the Bank of England in the battle to improve growth?
The Bank of England should take urgent action to promote growth. Their policies have been slowing the economy for months, as I have been warning.
Wokingham Conservatives had a war on potholes Saturday identifying  problems and reporting them to the Council  highways department for repairs. I'm sending in my findings.

Let's have an ownership revolution, with policies that encourage many more homeowners and small business owners. Stop the roll out of IR35, offer a better tax deal to the self employed, and ask the social housing providers to offer more affordable homes for purchase.
There is no need to give in on  fish to complete a Free Trade Agreement. The UK must be firm - no more concessions. An FTA is in the EU's interest so dig in.

The BBC Today programme was pressing to give away our fish to the EU, telling us it unrealistic to take back control.Why are they always on the EU's side? Catching our own fish and selling it at home or to the wider world is one of the big wins from Brexit which we must deliver.
Glad the National Trust want to plant more trees. They could start in our local woods where they ripped out big bushes and trees to remodel the landscape.

7% increase in value of the pound since October. Doubling of counter cyclical capital buffers for banks. Tough controls on car loans and consumer credit. This is a big monetary tighting. Time for the Bank to change course and join the Fed in fighting slowdown.
Poor retail sales are the predictable result of Mr Hammond's  fiscal squeeze and the Bank of England's money squeeze. Let's go for growth with new policies that promote it.
The government needs to give a boost to self employment and small business. Stopping IR 35 changes and cutting business rates should  be part of the growth policy.
I have asked the government if we are offering help to Australia in case they would welcome additional planes and naval vessels with equipment to fight fires and evacuate people.

London has many more small businesses per 1000 people than the rest of the country - twice as many as the lower income regions. Spreading wealth and prosperity widely to level the rest up to London requires a government drive to encourage many more new and small businesses.
More self employment and more businesses will be central to the government's policy of greater prosperity. They could give it an immediate boost by dropping their IR35 proposals.
Prosperity, growth and opportunity. 3 great positive words from the Prime Minister for the new decade. I look forward to helping put policies and action behind that vision. Happy New year.
It's great that we have a new Parliament for the new year which can get things done. We need to put prosperity for the many at the heart of all we do. Good start with a pay rise for those on low pay.

I'm looking forward to the next decade when the UK becomes an independent country again. We will be global in vision and outward looking. We will regain our vote and voice in international bodies. We can be a force for free trade and peace.

Can we talk about the policy change we need at the Bank of England from the new Governor? The Bank needs to follow policies that  support growth, as the Fed and ECB are doing, instead of generating a slowdown through excessive tightening.

The BBC this morning told us how the Pilgrim Fathers took democracy and freedom to America. It’s high time the BBC took a more positive line  on how Brexit is out to restore democratic freedoms here at home.

The WTO does not require us to impose new checks at borders or delay imports into the UK. They recommend risk based checks. As the risks of EU product will not go up the day we leave the EU there is no requirement to impose new difficult checks.

The EU has free trade agmts with a number of mainly smaller countries. 
Switzerland, for example has agreed to continue all current preferences with the UK on our exit. No country with an FTA with the EU has indicated any wish to terminate the agmt with the UK once we leave.

The one agmt we now have through the EU that may be important, the Gen Procurement Agmt, gives us access to public prcmt opportunities in signatory states & gives them the same access to the UK. The WTO agreed we will be a member of that Agmt in our own right on leaving the EU.

The EU does not have FTAs w/the USA, China, Brazil etc so we trade successfully w/ them under WTO rules & under the tariff schedule set by the EU. Once out we can sign Free Trade deals w/ these countries removing these tariffs or cld cut some of the tariffs unilaterally any time.

If this single market and customs union is such a great boon to us, how come our goods trade has scarcely grown with it for almost twenty years? And if trading under WTO rules is so difficult, how come our non EU trade is bigger than our EU trade and growing much faster?

The fall in the pound mainly occurred before the Brexit decision. It reached a peak of $1.71 on 6 July 2014.  It fell to a low of $1.38 on 28 February 2016, well before the referendum vote when the establishment and City were still all convinced we would vote to stay in.

Tax changes and a different mood towards diesels account for some of the fall. The April 2017 budget increased VED strongly for dearer new cars. April also saw the tightening of new car lending by the authorities which added to the problems in the car showrooms.

The fall in diesel car sales is nothing to do with Brexit. Car sales rose well against the background of a falling pound in the year before the Brexit vote, and rose strongly for the first nine months after the Brexit vote when the pound fell further.

How would a nationalised railway resolve disputes with employees that disrupt some private sector franchises? At least the periodic advertisement of franchises provides some modest competitive stimulus to better performance that would disappear w/ a wholly nationalised monopoly.

Nationalisation would impose an additional  financing strain on the state, but would not lead to much change in train services as the timetables, fare regulation and the provision of the bulk of the railway assets is already in state hands.

The idea that we should complete the nationalisation of  the railways means cancelling the train operating franchises, probably as they expire, and arranging finance to buy up trains to run as the train operations rejoin track provision and maintenance in the public sector.

We have a nationalised railway in all but name. All tracks, signals & stations are in public ownership run as a nationalised industry. Private train companies bid for a monopoly franchise on a route & must meet detailed specs for timetables & services from govt & rail regulators.

'Granny took on the wolf. She told him they had decided not to be in the EU any more so she didn't need to obey its rules. The Wolf replied it was not so easy. In the meantime the rules still applied. She told him what she thought of the rules & to mind his own business.'

'Mr EU Wolf was busily inspecting the vacuum cleaner to see if it complied with EU regulations to limit the power. He also sized up the bananas before joking that it was of course a myth that the EU wanted them to be straight. They were just fine, bent as they were.'

Latest car sales figures in the UK continue the poor trend I forecast which began in the spring with higher VED, a squeeze on car loans & the change of policy towards diesels. Diesel car sales down 16% year to date compared to last year, while petrol car sales are only up 3%.

Yesterday we were told that the UK plans to maintain open access for EU businesses coming to the UK under current rules, whether we leave with or without a deal.  Given our wish to have no new barriers, will the EU agree to the same?

The economic good news keeps flowing. The Nov CBI survey showed orders for manufacturing in the UK higher than any time since 1988. Retail sales cont'd to rise in real terms despite gloomy forecasts. Large sums have been invested in UK commercial property by overseas investors.

Having lobbied the Govt on access to high speed broadband I'm glad it has declined BT's proposal to deliver universal broadband by voluntary agmt. Labour MPs who use Parliamentary tactics to delay or derail Brexit are opposing the decision of UK voters in the referendum & the terms of their own Manifesto in 2017. To defy 1 expression of the public will is foolish. To defy 2 may prove v damaging to them in a future election.

It is true that Brexiteer MPs did often vote against new European laws, larger EU budgets and other increases in EU power under the Coalition. We did so because we took seriously the Conservative party Manifesto of 2010 which we had stood on.

An MP exercises judgement & holds the govt to account or is part of the govt. They were voted in because they belonged to a particular party as well as for their own merits. One must look at the general Manifesto of their Party when considering their later conduct.

A vision for an independent democratic UK
https://t.co/8hrDDPP1DR

We did not vote to be some minor state following meekly the EU’s laws and policies. We voted for our country to regain its vote and voice in global bodies. We voted to be friends and trading partners with the EU, but not to be part of its legal system and budgets.

The people reasserted their sovereignty. They now wish Parliament to act in their interests by spending the taxes raised on our priorities & to pass wise & humane laws. They want the Govt to have a confident global vision, to act in the best interests of the UK & the wider good.

The Cabinet this week  debates what kind of a country we wish to be, and how we should be governed once we leave the EU. The vision of Leave was uplifting. We want to belong to an independent democratic country. We want to take back control of our laws, our borders and our money.

The public are not in favour of making large payments to the EU without good reason, or even at all in many cases. The Government will need to show a good wide ranging Agreement to persuade people to accept a generous settlement.

Opponents of the Govt include numerous opposition MPs & lobbyists who want to slow or delay Brexit. They see Transition as another 2 years in the EU paying our contributions & accepting all old & new laws as if we were still full members w/o any voice or vote on what the EU does.

In transition it would be best if the UK were not subject to the ECJ, freedom of movement & restrictions on negotiating trade deals. As we are assured we are leaving on 29/3/19 these won't apply unless we enact them into UK law for a period in furtherance of an Agreement w/the EU

The Prime Minister has always been very clear. She has said we will need an Implementation period, assuming we have an Agreement to implement.  She has also rightly said this Implementation period should not be longer than needed.

I am pleased to see the government does intend to put the departure date into the Withdrawal Bill. It needs to be there to ensure continuity of law on the day we leave, which will be 29 March 2019 according to the Treaty procedure.

Article 50 makes clear we will leave automatically on 29/3/19, 2 years from the letter so it's vital that we have in place a proper legal framework. Given the enthusiasm of the Govt’s critics for Parliamentary democracy, surely our leaving date is worthy of primary legislation.

There is now discussion of the Gov't amendment to place the date of exit in the Bill. I hope the Gov't does continue with this amendment & work to ensure its passage. We need the date in the Bill to ensure legal continuity.

Underlying this fairly technical debate was a series of other agendas. The Lib Dems openly seek to delay & disrupt Brexit as they wish to reverse the public decision. Many Remain Labour MPs want to slow & water it down because they don't really accept the judgement of the people.

On Wednesday Amend. 7 passed against the Govt's wishes. The argument was one of detail, not of principle. Both Gov't & its critics accepted that Parliament is back in charge over Brexit. Both accepted that any UK/EU Agreement which may be reached should be voted on in Parliament.

The Government has won all but one of the votes on the EU Withdrawal Bill. The most important vote, the one to approve Clause 1 which repeals the 1972 European Communities Act, passed by 318 to 68, as Labour accepted they needed to allow the repeal to permit Brexit.

From my interview on Talk Radio with @JuliaHB1. Labour and Lib Dem MPs saw last night’s vote as a way of inflicting damage on the British government to undermine Brexit but it is not the end of the Bill and does it not end the Brexit process.

What kind of defence policy do we want? First & foremost must be home defence. By a combination of diplomacy, foreign policy & military deterrence we wish to keep our islands from military threat. We also need to ensure we have the force needed to defend ourselves if needed.

The Govt has published a draft bill which would increase the max prison sentence for animal cruelty from 6 months to 5 years. The Loddon Christmas concert was very enjoyable. The primary school choirs from the Borough excelled themselves. Last Friday I visited CEMAS in Wokingham. It employs 72 people & specialises in preparing test data for the agro chemical & pharmaceutical industries.  V. impressed by their Professional Placement scheme which gives work placement experience to Reading University undergraduates. https://t.co/Tg7bhcwHjF

There are many misunderstandings abt regulatory alignment & convergence. When you trade w/ a country or trading bloc you must meet its requirements & product rules to sell to them. What you don't do is also accept all its rules & laws to govern the rest of your trade.

We only need an Implementation Agreement if there is an Agreement on future trade & partnership to implement. The idea shouldn't be to create a further 2 years in the EU u/ the guise of a Transitional Agreement to have another 2 years of uncertainty & more talks about trade.

The UK needs to stress the urgency of getting on with the free trade talks. It's accepted we only sign a free trade agreement after we have left but we need to know the details of such an agreement before we leave to judge the rest of the Agreement & the phasing of implementation

Early next year we should begin talks about trade and the future relationship with the EU. Until we do so the language developed over money and the Irish border is parked. Both sides confirmed “Nothing is agreed until all is agreed”.

Will the PM agree that when we leave, with or without a deal, we will trade under WTO terms. This includes the trade facilitation agreement which allows progress over borders for WTO members. Doesn’t this strengthen our position when she gets a good deal? https://t.co/DvQmdOpXcT https://t.co/W5AxBhMy7y

We have a year to source alternative cheaper food from around the world and for our farms to gear up to produce more at home behind the tariff wall. If the EU for example wants a high tariff on meat there are plenty of other suppliers who would like to sell us more.

The EU could, if it wishes, impose the same tariffs on our goods and food exports as they do to other non EU countries under WTO rules which govern us both. This would mean they would face high tariffs on their large farm exports to us, where they run a £20 bn surplus.

If the answer is No to a free trade deal, then the UK needs to ask the second question. What new tariffs and barriers does the EU wish to impose on our exports to them, given that we will likely impose identical barriers on their exports to us?

If the EU want a free trade agreement we can get on with translating our current tariff free arrangements on goods into a WTO registerable Free Trade Agreement, along with the access methods for service covered by current EU arrangements.
The first question the UK must ask when the talks begin is the simple one. Does the EU want a comprehensive free trade Agreement with us or not?

I have in the past said trade talks between the UK and the EU could be relatively short and straight forward. I have never said they would be. I have always acknowledged that if the EU wants to make them long and complex they can do so.

The detailed draft agreement on citizens rights & on a financial settlement are without prejudice to an agreement on a future relationship. The Prime Minister has stated that the payment of any money other than our contributions up to leaving are contingent on a wider Agreement.
The Joint Report on Negotiations opens by stressing that both sides are pledged to the view that nothing is agreed until everything is agreed. https://t.co/9t2QqJkOt5

We need to remember that leaving on the WTO option means no add'l payments to the EU, whilst taking back control of our borders, our laws & our money. A good deal has to be better than this, otherwise the Government’s mantra that No Deal is better than a bad deal should apply.

Everyone needs to remember that today's agreement is not the Agreement on the UK leaving the EU. It is an agreement to talk about all matters, and is still governed by the crucial principle that nothing is agreed until everything is agreed.

Today we learn that the EU is now prepared to talk about trade and the future relationship as well as the three special subjects it singled out for discussion so far. That is welcome, and means there can now be serious negotiations about a future Agreement.

There are now 1.9m more children in good or outstanding schools as assessed by Ofsted than in 2010. Raising reading standards is an important part of raising educational standards, as so much learning rests on reading and understanding the written word.

This week came the good news that English schools have done well in boosting reading standards in recent years. England now ranks 8th out of 50 countries at reading, compared to being 19th out of 45 in 2006. This improvement has been fastest for the lower performing pupils.

My hope for this Christmas and the New Year is that we can make more progress in putting behind us wars in the Middle East and to work with the UN and other interested nations to promote more dialogue and less bombing.

It could be time to think again about how the railway can sell more seats, collect more overall revenue, but go a bit easier on the reliable captive passengers who need to commute to work.

The recent rail fare increases have been unwelcome.  Season tickets are now very expensive over longer commuting distances.  The present artificial scarcity of train seats into our main cities is used as an excuse for high prices for season tickets.

UK unemployment fell to 4.3% in November, a new low since 1975. The economy over the last year continued to generate a large number of additional jobs. This good result was not the one many forecasters assumed, as they expected a downturn which did not happen.

There have been some welcome improvements in the Universal Credit. More money will be made available earlier for claimants, w/ the 7 day waiting period going in February. The housing component can be paid directly to landlords. Interest free advances can be made to new claimants.

The Government reports that people find faster routes into work from Universal Credit which is designed to make it always worthwhile working. They estimate another 250,000 getting into work as Universal Credit is rolled out. Promoting work helps people achieve higher incomes.

The idea behind benefit reform is to simplify the complex benefits system, ensure financial support for those who need it, and to make it easier to get into work. Labour used to support the general aims of the reform, but they now want to slow down its implementation.

I have encouraged Wokingham BC to help town traders during the period of disruption from building works. They agreed to remove council car parking charges for shoppers going into Wokingham on 3 week-ends before Christmas from 9 Dec & will be free after 3 each day until e/of Jan.

I strongly support the Govt's Green Paper which sets out measures to improve mental health support for children & young people. You can contribute to the consultation which ends on 2 March 2018 at: https://t.co/r8eCiGueQl  You can also contact me directly.

Mental health problems affect a significant number of children & young people, often negatively affecting their life chances. Some of my constituents have had difficulties in accessing mental health services for their children. The Govt wants to transform services for the young.

Yesterday showed how far the EU wish to push the UK even to get to talks abt a future Agreement. Talks ended in disagreement on Irish border issues. I support the Govt's stated view that it must take back control of our money, borders & laws & no deal is better than a bad deal.

Google too has grown quickly in London & is taking substantial space. It is working on a 1 million square foot headquarters at Kings Cross. The new economy majors see the UK as a fast growing opportunity. These latest investments are important for future UK growth & development.

The new Facebook headquarters is a timely reminder of how the business community sees us. It appreciates the UK as a source of talented employees, a good base for business, and a place that offers world class accommodation and facilities.

We can only only take back control of our laws, money & borders if we leave with no further commitments to EU jurisdiction. We must remind them there's no legal requirement to pay a so called divorce bill. I still want us to spend our money on our own priorities the day we leave.

Two views of Brexit - There are others who seem to think after Brexit we need to mirror all the arrangements and controls we had when in the EU. They also seem to think the UK is in a weak position so they recommend making many concessions to the EU negotiating position.

Two views of Brexit - Brexit continues to dominate the media because there remain two different views of how to implement it. There are those in the civil service who understand the wish of the majority to leave.  They are working diligently on what can come as soon as we leave.

I raised again the issue of making better use of railway property & keeping it in good order as well as good co-operation on providing more bridge capacity over the railway lines as the major east-west rail routes in our area create a substantial barrier to north-south traffic.

I held a meeting this week with the Rail Delivery Group about how to expand capacity and improve services on the railways.  Among the issues I raised was digital signalling, which can lead to running more trains safely on the same track.

When the pound was going down we had daily reports of how worrying this was, usually ascribed for no good reason to Brexit. The pound at $1.35 is now up by 12.5% from its recent low, but there is little comment & no features on newscasts.

Both sides to the negotiations say they wish to keep the Common Travel area so there is no need for new border barriers to deal with people. The UK & the Irish authorities already have in place methods for dealing w/ illegal migrants & criminals seeking entry.

People who claim there has to be a hard border once we leave the EU need to understand the nature of the current border. While it's true there are no custom dues to levy on products within the EU crossing the border it is still a currency, VAT, Income & Corporation tax border.

One of the many wrong forecasts by official bodies before the referendum was a likely fall in house prices and in housebuilding after a No vote. Almost a year and half later, house prices are up modestly and housebuilding has expanded by around 15%.

The Govt has made great strides with the Think Autism strategy but I am aware that challenges still remain in accessing mental health services.  With this in mind I have written to the Secretary of State to ask what can be done to provide autism specific mental health services.

No Deal ticks 4 of the 5 boxes of what we want from Brexit. We get control of our borders, laws & money. No special divorce bill & we can negotiate trade agreements around the world. It doesn't deliver a free trade agreement w/ the EU tho after Brexit they may decide it want one.

Schools must be properly funded & good teachers valued & supported. It is also a task for the community & families. It may only take a comment or word of support to make the difference for a young person. It's for us to show there is opportunity for all & effort can be rewarded.

We have expanded educational opportunity substantially, by effectively raising the school leaving age and increasing the number of university places on offer. There is no ceiling on how well any individual can do, no firm limit on how many good degrees are awarded.

The ambition of improving people’s living standards is shared across the UK political spectrum. The arguments are in practice all about how we achieve that, though some seek to misrepresent the views of others by implying some do not want people to succeed.
You don't pay to talk. You only move forward on the basis of mutual goodwill and agreement.

The UK also now has the opportunity to set up its own Medicine Agency as we leave the EU. Given the high regard for UK science this could be well received by the world community, and could attract other countries to want to use its facilities and adopt its standards.

One of the main problems of Parties in Europe is they cannot offer much change in economic policy given the way the Euro scheme works. Locked into policies which electors do not like voters turn instead to new & noisier parties in the hope they will break out of the EU consensus.

It looks as if the collapse of the old main parties on the continent is a Euro area phenomenon related to economic pressures within the zone,leading to identity issues affecting national and regional politics. It is curious how the grand old parties allow this decline to happen.

Mrs Merkel’s bad loss of votes & seats in the German election was part of a continental pattern. In almost every EU member state there's been a similar collapse in support for the 2 traditional parties of the centre left & centre right that alternated in govt in the last century.

In the Budget the Chancellor announced that Sir Oliver Letwin will lead an Inquiry into how the build rate can be speeded up to avoid the unplanned consequences of failure to use existing permissions. I will take this up again with the Inquiry.

Wokingham Borough has ok'd a substantial number of planning permissions for new homes. Sometimes developers don't build at the pace the local plan would like. Others apply for additional planning permission as the build rate is too slow. The Council & I raised this w/ the Govt.

Number plate recognition technology can be used at NI/ROI road border points to ensure the necessary registrations & payments occur without the need for physical barriers or stops. Smaller consignments by small businesses living near the border can be exempted.

The likely approach will be for the larger importers and exporters to register as Authorised Economic Operators. They will be able to file electronic paperwork about truck consignments in advance of travel b/w NOI & ROI.

The current NI/ROI border is a VAT & currency border. Goods & services entailing cross border transactions have paperwork/electronic filing to handle the different tax regimes & any currency adjustments. If we end up with the WTO model it's possible to add a customs tariff line.

The ROI & NI have enjoyed a Common Travel area for many years. It pre dated our entry into the EEC. There is no wish to change this on exit. People will be free to cross the Ireland/Northern Ireland border as today.

As we don't owe anything the best thing to do is to offer nothing to the EU. The public show in polls that they have no wish to pay large sums to the EU. It is time to spend the money at home instead.

Some seem to think we should nonetheless pay something to get a deal. It is most important that this is always called an ex gratia payment or gift, as the UK must not by its language and promises create some legal obligation under EU law that does not exist at the moment.

There is general agreement that there is no legal requirement for the UK to pay the EU anything on exit. There is no provision in the Treaty for an exit bill.  No one in the referendum campaign said we would face a bill & the EU has never produced a legal base for a divorce bill.
